awd_titl_txt: MRI:   Development of a Flexible Instrument and Tools for Experimental Research in Next-Generation 9-1-1 Services
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal #:	CNS 08-21736
PI(s):		Dantu, Ram
		Guturu, Parthasarathy; Kavi, Krishna M.
Institution:	University of North Texas
		Denton, TX 76203-5250
Title: MRI/Dev:A Flexible Instrument and Tools for Experimental Research in Next Generation 9-1-1 Services
Project Proposed:
This project, developing a flexible instrument and tools for research to understand and analyze next-generation 9-1-1 services, contributes to the process of planning next-generation emergency communication infrastructure. The instrument will house and evaluate the techniques for locating 9-1-1 callers, securing public safety answering points (PSAPs), ensuring continuous availability of 9-1-1 services during large-scale emergencies, providing neighborhood notifications, improving interagency coordination, and enhancing 9-1-1 services for the deaf and hearing-impaired through video phones and instant messaging. Additional goals include measuring the performance of  LoST (location to service translation), LCP (location configuration), and SIPLC (SIP location conveyance) protocols used in PSAP; developing a tool for performance measurements for call processing and security (PSAP), translating the development efforts to engineering guidelines, and disseminating the results across government organizations, standards bodies such as the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF), and the National Emergency Number Association (NENA) and 9-1-1 centers. NENA and Denco 9-1-1 center support testing and validation of the tools and instrument. Thus, the project develops 
-	A flexible, high performance instrument and tools for locating callers, specifically to investigate security and scalability of next-generation 9-1-1 technology,
-	The instrumentation required for investigation of several research issues related to 9-1-1 notifications during disaster, and
-	A dissemination and educational program to transfer the results to industry and government agencies.

Broader Impacts:
 This project enables new research and education in 9-1-1 services. Workshops will be organized (3 have been held in VoIP security) and dissemination will be forthcoming. The research projects enabled will be helpful to deaf and hearing- and speech-impaired individuals.

por.por_cntn:
Next Generation 9-1-1 systems will bring with them an enormous level of potential.  The use of SIP as a major infrastructural component allows for extending 9-1-1 operator capabilities in new and exciting ways.  The wide array of sensors within smart phones allow new types of information to be gathered beyond the traditional audio or even video.

Location Detection in High Rise Buildings

Locating a person calling 9-1-1 is not a trivial task, particularly when they are in a building where GPS is not available.  Using the magnetometer on a phone and the Dynamic Time Warping algorithm, we developed a methodology of determining an individual's location based on the surrounding magnetic field with > 90% accuracy.  Our methodology leverages the magnetic field variations within a building caused by the building's structure, materials, and electrical power systems.  These variations give different locations within a building a unique fingerprint.  In turn, these fingerprints can then be compiled together to create a “magnetic map.”

Communication Quality

We used ClearSight Analyzer to measure RTP video quality in reference to different resolutions, frame rates, and codecs.  Some of the codecs used included Theora, H.261, and MPEG standard.  Quality was measured using “VQFactor”, a proprietary ClearSight metric.  When bit rate was varied using a constant video resolution, quality was seen to correlate directly with bitrate.  When bitrate was held constant and resolution was varied, we found that quality declined with increasing video resolution.  Furthermore, based on our experiments, we concluded that large screen size is not necessarily required for perceived video quality to be good.

Smart Phone Resource Strain

Video calls will put a much higher strain on smart phone hardware than audio calls.  We found that during a video call on the Google Nexus One, a phone with a 1 GHz Qualcomm Scorpion CPU, video takes up an average of 12-15% of CPU time during a call.  We also found that video with movement has negligible impact on CPU usage compared to still video.

New Capabilities

SIP may be extended to give the operator a greater amount of information by creating new types of SIP INFO messages.  For example, an INFO message may carry information about a caller's health status or phone capabilities.  However, we also found that there is potential for issues with some SIP proxies as they may filter out unknown INFO messages.

Remote Media Control

A smart phone is equipped with a wide array of capabilities, many of which are not available in a telephone application or may be very difficult for a caller to find.  We developed a SIP INFO message based protocol designed to allow the operator to query the caller's phone for capabilities which are then used to control the phone remotely.  This implementation allows new features to be added to a phone with no change on the operator side which eliminates any platform dependence.
